thread.title: Sounders shut out Vancouver, 3-0, win Cascadia Cup
thread.title_full: Sounders shut out Vancouver, 3-0, win Cascadia Cup | The Seattle Times

author: Matt Pentz
title: Sounders shut out Vancouver, 3-0, win Cascadia Cup
text:
VANCOUVER, B.C. — His teammates called Gonzalo Pineda’s second-half strike a FIFA goal. “The trick button and the curler into the upper 90 with the left foot,” Seattle goalkeeper Stefan Frei said.
Pineda called it one of the best goals of his career, as well as an important burst of light in a season that has played out mostly in the shade.
From a wider lens, Pineda’s goal looked like the one that finally broke Vancouver’s resolve, the one that locked up Seattle’s first Cascadia Cup since 2011 and helped the Sounders take one giant leap toward the MLS playoffs.
Pineda’s goal was the second of three — Andreas Ivanschitz scored his first MLS goal just before halftime and Obafemi Martins finished off a Clint Dempsey assist late — as the Sounders walloped their rivals 3-0 on Saturday afternoon at BC Place.
Most Read Stories Doug Baldwin struggles to find balance between football and life 3 couples imagine a new kind of retirement on Bainbridge Island Chinese president’s visit could wreak havoc on region’s traffic Green River killer Ridgway coming back to Washington How Vietnamese-Americans in Bellevue challenged an insensitive art display — and won Unlimited Digital Access. $1 for 4 weeks. Coupled with San Jose’s 3-2 loss at New York City, the Sounders are now five points clear of the playoff cutoff line with four matches remaining.
Their late-season leveling off has taken place with Pineda edged out of the picture. Prior to last Saturday’s draw against the Earthquakes, the veteran midfielder had started just one match since early July.
Match stats
Nagging injuries hadn’t helped his status, nor had the glut of new signings during the summer transfer window. But Erik Friberg was hurt at practice on Friday and Pineda lined up alongside Osvaldo Alonso in midfield, with captain Brad Evans out wide and Zach Scott replacing injured Roman Torres in defense.
Scott knows the drill.
“It always seems like around this time, that’s when I start playing again,” Scott said. “That’s all I can worry about, just being right there on the cusp, pushing the guys in front of you, and when you get an opportunity, take it and run. Gonzo (Pineda) is the same way. All the veterans are the same way.”
Pineda’s moment came with less than 20 minutes remaining of a game that had been tilted toward Seattle’s penalty box.
The first half had been cautiously optimistic.
Vancouver likes to sit back, lull teams into a false sense of security then bite them on the counterattack. That strategy has paid dividends: Despite averaging one of the lowest possession totals in MLS, the Whitecaps entered the weekend in first place in the Supporters’ Shield standings.
But when opponents hesitate to commit numbers, wary of giving the ’Caps too much space, their games get stagnant.
The game was moping lazily toward halftime when Martins picked out Andreas Ivanschitz with a pinpoint pass in front of goal, the Austrian playmaker setting it with a touch before finishing past Whitecaps ’keeper David Ousted. Ivanschitz, too, has suffered through a long summer, first training on his own to stay sharp and getting injured almost as soon as Seattle signed him.
Vancouver pressed higher in the second half, peppering Frei with shots. Seattle didn’t keep the ball for very long but looked potent on the break while it did.
Martins and Dempsey started finding each other, foreshadowing the final dagger to come, when Martins put the finishing touch on Dempsey’s muscle-flexing surge through the Whitecaps’ back line.
But an all-important insurance tally eluded the Sounders until the moment Pineda found Martins in the 71st minute. Martins picked out substitute Nelson Valdez, who knocked it back to Dempsey with a deft touch. Dempsey played it to Pineda, who patiently waited for an opening.
Pineda’s curler bounced off the left post on the way in, and he sprinted toward the corner to celebrate with his teammates.
Pineda, one of those team-always-comes-first vets, then stole a moment for himself. Strolling toward midfield, he looked upward at the underside of the closed BC Place roof and spread his arms as if in prayer.
“I was thinking about my family,” Pineda said. “Sometimes, when I’m not playing and I’m not happy, that happens the same at home. I’m not in a good mood, sometimes, with my family, and they’re always supporting me to get my head clean. I just wanted to say thank you.”
Cascadia Cup winners The Cascadia Cup goes to the head-to-head winner among the three Northwest MLS teams each year. Year Team 2004 Vancouver 2005 Vancouver 2006 Seattle 2007 Seattle 2008 Vancouver 2009 Portland 2010 Portland 2011 Seattle 2012 Portland 2013 Vancouver 2014 Vancouver 2015 Seattle Source: thecascadiacup.com Matt Pentz: 206-464-3184 or mpentz@seattletimes.com . On Twitter @mattpentz
